Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The Hay Canyon Amine Plant consists of a number of production
units and/or scrubbers to remove liquids from the natural gas
process stream, an amine unit to remove carbon dioxide, and a
Joule-Thompson  (JT)  expansion unit to extract  natural  gas
liquids  (NGL).   On  a  daily basis the  facility  processes
approximately 4 to 5 million standard cubic feet  (MMscf)  of
dehydrated  natural  gas per day and the  JT  expansion  unit
extracts  approximately 800 gallons of  NGL.  The  NGL  is  a
flammable  mixture consisting of multiple regulated flammable
substances  including methane, ethane, propane,  butane,  and
pentane.    Included  with  the  regulated   flammables   are
additional non-regulated flammables in the C-6 through  C-10+
range.   The  NGL  is  stored at ambient  temperatures  in  a
pressure  vessel  maintained at  approximately  230  psig  to
control  vapor  release.  The various  production  units  and
scrubbers  remove  produced water  and  condensate  from  the
process  stream and direct the liquids to either of  two  (2)
100  barrel  (bbl) vertical atmospheric storage  tanks  (slop
tanks).  The slop liquids mixture contains multiple regulated
flammable  substances  including  methane,  ethane,  propane,
butane,  and pentane.  Included with the regulated flammables
are additional non-regulated flammables in the C-6 through C-
10+  range. There are no regulated toxic materials stored  at

General Accidental Release Prevention Program
The  Hay Canyon Amine Plant is located in a remote area  with
no  identified residential occupancies within more than  one-
half  mile  of the locations of regulated flammable  storage.
There  are  no full-time employees assigned to the  facility.
The  estimated presence of onsite personnel is 4 to  6  hours
per  day.   As  such,  this facility is considered  to  be  a
normally unoccupied remote facility (NURF) and is not covered
by the OSHA process safety management (PSM) standard.

Employee Participation. All employees are trained in accident
prevention  and  emergency response as part of  their  formal
training.  An Emergency Response Plan has been prepared  that
identifies  specific employee responsibilities and responses,
and  lists  the reporting requirements, names, and  telephone
numbers for key company personnel.  Employees are expected to
participate in the Company's Hazard Identification Program.

Design  Codes and Standards.  The facility is newly  designed
and constructed.  The design standards follow the most recent
code  requirements including, where appropriate, ASTM,  ASME,
API, and NEC.

Process  Hazard Analysis.  An initial hazard review has  been
performed  by  facility personnel to identify  major  hazards
that   might  be  encountered.   This  hazard  identification
includes  the  following  potential items:  fire,  explosion,
overpr

essurization,    corrosion,   overfilling,    equipment
failure, and loss of plant utilities.  Following the  initial
hazard  review, periodic updates at least every 5  years  and
after  any major process change, unplanned event, or  release
will be conducted.

Various process controls are in place to regulate the process
and  prevent  any  unplanned events.  The  process  equipment
includes  various vents, relief valves, check valves,  manual
shutoffs,  automatic  shutoffs, equipment  interlocks,  level
monitors,  and  flow  meters  to  maintain  normal   control.
Unexpected excess vapor can be relieved through safety relief
valves.  Alarm systems continuously monitor the process.  The
monitoring information can be accessed on-site, and  is  also
transmitted  to the offsite central Gas Control Center  where
it is monitored by operating personnel 24-hours per day.

There  are  no  dikes  or  containment  structures  for   the
pressurized   flammable  substance   storage   tanks.    This
provision  is  intentional  and designed  to  allow  volatile
liquid  spills  to  dissipate and spread  over  the  greatest
possible  area  and  evaporate.   Use  of  dikes  around  the
pressure  tanks would contain a liquid pool, and a  resulting
pool fire could overheat the pressure tanks causing a greater
hazard than the original evaporating spill.  With respect  to
the  pressurized  storage tank, no direct mitigation  systems
are  in general use.  No area release monitoring or detection
systems  are  in  use other than the unit  and  tank  process
alarms  from equipment failure, high level, high temperature,
or high pressure.

Operator  Training. Operators have written  instructions  for
normal    operations   and   emergency   responses.     These
instructions  include  normal  and  emergency   startup   and
shutdown,  as  well  as a variety of special  procedures  for
restarting  and adjusting various components of the  process.
In  addition

to  the written procedures, there  are  various
supplemental  training activities including safety  meetings,
internet-based  self  instruction, and  on-the-job  training.
Training   is   verified  by  a  combination  of   documented
experience,   observational  methods  and   verbal   testing.
Training   is  documented  in  writing,  and  reinforced   by
refresher training at least every three years.
Contractors.    The  facility uses  various  contractors  for
major   plant   modifications  and  for  specific   scheduled
preventative   maintenance   and   unscheduled    maintenance
operations.  Contractors are required to attend a site safety
briefing   at   the  start  of  any  new  work.   Contractors
performing  continuing  services  are  required  to   provide
documentation of training to facility personnel.

Compliance Audits.  Compliance audits of the general facility
including reporting and recordkeeping, operator, maintenance,
and  contractor compliance will be scheduled as the  facility
comes  on-line.  To-date, no audits have been performed other
than those associated with construction quality assurance.

Incident  Investigation.  Incidents (involving a catastrophic
release)   will   be   documented  and   investigated.    The
investigation will begin within 48 hours of the release,  and
a  written  analysis  of  the cause and  recommendations  for
future  prevention will be prepared, discussed with  affected
personnel,  and retained for a minimum of 5 years.   To-date,
there have been no catastrophic incidents.

Five-Year Accident History
The facility is newly constructed and to-date there have been
no   accidents  involving  regulated  substances  that   have
resulted  in  any  onsite  injuries or  significant  property
damage or any offsite response.

Emergency Response Program
A general Emergency Response Plan (ERP) has been prepared for
several  EnCana  facilities, including the Hay  Canyon  Amine
Plant.  This

general plan includes specific  actions  for  a
variety of personnel, ranging from first responder to  senior
management.   There  is a comprehensive  list  of  names  and
telephone numbers in the ERP for key Hay Canyon personnel and
Hay Canyon emergency responders.  The primary response agency
is  the Rangley, Colorado fire department.  In addition,  the
emergency  response  program is  also  coordinated  with  the
Garfield County local emergency planning committee (LEPC)  in
Glenwood  Springs.    The  ERP is periodically  reviewed  and
updated as conditions require.

Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
The Hay Canyon Amine Plant is a new facility located about 24
miles  north  of Loma, Colorado. The plant is  located  in  a
rural  area  about 0.4 of a mile from Highway 139  near  mile
marker  24.   The  plant receives dehydrated natural  gas  by
pipeline, removes condensable natural gas liquids (NGLs)  and
carbon dioxide, and ultimately delivers the natural gas to  a
transmission pipeline.

Operators  of  the  facility have an on-going  commitment  to
safety   and   accident  prevention.   This   commitment   is
demonstrated by upper managements support of an  active  EH&S
program. An employee training program is implemented as  part
of  a  comprehensive EH&S management system and  the  use  of
established  design  and construction standards  (API,  ASME,
NEC),  and  the  installation of a state-of-the  art  process
control  and monitoring system.  The facility was constructed
by  skilled  tradesmen who, in many cases, were  required  to
demonstrate  their skills and pass certification requirements
prior  to  working  on  the project.   On-going  construction
inspection  and  quality assurance procedures included  x-ray
examination  of welds for additional quality control.   Shop-
fabricated  equipment mounted on skid units were  used  where
possible to minimize field construction.

At  this  facility, critical process parameters are monitored
remotely  on  a 24-hour basis using supervisory  control  and
data acquisition (SCADA) technologies.  This approach enables
operation  without  full-time onsite  personnel.   The  SCADA
systems permit both automated and operator-directed responses
to  process  conditions  in addition to  providing  immediate
annunciation

lity.  A plot plan of the facility is  included  in
the offsite consequence analysis for the facility.

Offsite Consequence Analysis
At  the subject facility, regulated flammable substances  are
generated  and stored as a result of two separate operations;
the  separation of slop liquids, and the extraction  of  NGL.
The  slop and NGL storage vessels are not connected,  however
the  storage  vessels for the two operations are  located  in
close  proximity.   Due  to the lack of intervening  distance
between  the  slop  and  NGL vessels,  a  fire  or  explosion
involving   the  vessels  related  to  one  operation   could
potentially  spread  to the storage vessels  for  the  second
operation.   Therefore,  for  the  purpose  of  the   offsite
consequence analysis, the slop and NGL vessels are considered
to be one process.

The  worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a  release  of
flammable  substances from the subject facility  is  a  vapor
cloud  explosion  (VCE)  involving  the  full  inventory   of
flammable  materials  for  both  the  NGL  and  slop  storage
vessels,  including  flammable  materials  contained  in  the
associated piping.  The endpoint for the consequence analysis
is  the  extent of the 1 psi overpressure resulting from  the
VCE.

At  the  subject  facility,  the total  volume  of  flammable
materials  is  27,200 gallons, assuming that  the  associated
piping  contains 3% of the storage volume.  For the WCS,  the
entire flammable material inventory is assumed to release and
ignite resulting in a VCE.  There are numerous safety systems
and   administrative  controls  to  prevent  such   releases,
including  physical isolation of the tanks,  pressure  relief
valves, remotely operated shut-off valves, and remote  level,
pressure,  and temperature monitoring; however no credit  for
administrative or passive mitigation measures was  considered
for evaluating the WCS.
